Albania: Italy suspended economic support to Albania.
Bangladesh: Surya Sen was hanged on 12 January 1934 by the British rulers following the arrest in February 1933.
Barbados: Grantley Adams is elected to the House of Assembly.
Belgium:
Death of Albert I, King of the Belgians.
Birth of King Albert II of Belgium
Brazil:
The Vargas government introduces what will be the shortest-lived Constitution of Brazil, lasting only 3 years (until 1937). It is the first time a Brazilian constitution has been written from scratch by directly elected deputies in multi-party elections, and incorporates a number of improvements to Brazilian political, social and economical life.
In the presidential election, carried out by the Constituent Assembly, acting president Getúlio Vargas receives 175 of the 248 votes.
The University of São Paulo is established.
The Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics is founded under the title of the National Institute of Statistics.
Chile: Women obtain the legal right to vote in municipal elections.
China: Chiang and his wife Soong Mei-ling established the quasi-fascist New Life Movement. Long March: The Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army broke through the KMT lines attempting to encircle them at Ganzhou.
Colombia:
Alfonso López Pumarejo is president of Colombia
First census in Colombia. Population:8.700.000
Cuba:
The One Hundred Days Government ends; Carlos Hevia serves briefly as president.
Manuel Márquez Sterling is president for a few hours, followed by Carlos Mendieta.
ABC holds a demonstration at the Havana festival and its march is attacked by radical forces, including those of  Antonio Guiteras.
Estonia:
New constitution in effect.
Konstantin Päts with the help of General Johan Laidoner set up a virtual dictatorship. Parliament was prorogued and political parties were banned. Many members of the Vaps Movement were arrested.
France: Riots by far-right leagues were repressed by the state in what was considered as a failed coup d'état, and a major political crisis of the Third Republic.
Germany: Night of the Long Knives: SS paramilitaries killed at least eighty-five potential threats to Hitler's power, including SA head Ernst Röhm and Gregor Strasser, head of the left wing of the Nazi Party. Hitler issued a law merging the powers of the presidency into the office of the chancellor. Hindenburg died from lung cancer.
Haiti:
President of the United States Franklin D. Roosevelt visits Cap-Haïtien
Last American forces withdraw from Haiti, ending the U.S. occupation
The flag of Haiti is raised at Casernes Dessalines, where it was lowered nineteen years earlier at the start of the U.S. occupation
Italy: The Italian national football team wins its first FIFA World Cup.
Latvia: Prime Minister Kārlis Ulmanis took power in a bloodless coup d'état.
Malta: English and Maltese are declared the official languages of Malta, to the exclusion of Italian which had been the primary language of government, commerce, education and culture in Malta for more than 800 years.
Philippine: The Tydings-McDuffie Law, known as the Philippine Independence Law, is approved by U.S. President Roosevelt.
A pearl, which would be one of the world’s largest, is found in Palawan.
202 delegates are elected to the Constitutional Convention in accordance with the Tydings-McDuffie Act
The Philippine Constitutional Convention is inaugurated
Bannawag, Ilocos region's weekly vernacular magazine, established.
Poland: Signing of the German–Polish Non-Aggression Pact
Russia:
Elections to the Central Committee at the Seventeenth Party Congress revealed Sergey Kirov, the chief of the Leningrad Party, to be the most popular member.
The Main Directorate of State Security (GUGB) was established under the NKVD as a successor to the OGPU.
Kirov was murdered by Leonid Nikolaev, possibly at the behest of Stalin.
Serbia: King Alexander I of Yugoslavia is shot dead by the Bulgarian and Croatian fascists, Vlado Chernosemski and the Ustaše. Prince Paul temporarily seizes the throne. Alexander's son Peter II was a minor at the time.
Singapore: Sir Shenton Thomas was appointed as the Governor of the Straits Settlements.
Slovenia:
The Balkan Entente formed between Romania, the Kingdom of Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey.
The king Alexander I. Karađorđević, who reigned since 1921, is assassinated in Marseille together with a French foreign minister Louis Barthou by Croatian extremist nationalists.
Sweden: Crisis in the Population Question (Kris i befolkningsfrågan) by Alva and Gunnar Myrdal published and plays major role in design of Sweden's welfare policy
Switzerland: Creates numbered bank accounts, giving account holder anonymity.
